reviews.review_title: Great Action and Drama from the beginning
reviews.content: Denzel Washington gave an unbelievable performance in this movie. This movie was great from the opening scene to the closing scene. All action, pure action and many twists. It is a movie I could see over and over again

***SPOILERS***   ***SPOILERS*** Some of the scene depicted the streets in an exciting way, but the storyline was so flawed it took the rest of the movie down with it.There was NO reason for Denzel Washington to involve Ethan Hawke in any of his dirty doings at all. What kind of killer-crook involves an innocent person ( Hawke ) and then kills someone in front of him hoping he'll take the blame for it??? Absurd! Denzel should have offed Scott Glenn himself privately and taken all the money. All he basically did was pluck an innocent person out of the police academy and make him a witness to a zillion crimes when Denzel already had enough legitimate dirty goons around to do whatever he wanted. It was completely unnecessary.

From the moment I sat in my seat until the end of Training Day, the ride was unbelievable; absolutely incredible. There were those first few quite and terse moments before Ethan Hawke(Jake Hoyt)meets Denzel Washington(Alonzo Harris). SPOILER!!Hoyt's at home with his wife and new baby and is excited at the chance he's been given to join an elite LAPD narc unit. Hawke(Hoyt)meets his would be mentor and it's off the hook from then on. The Dr. Dre and Snoop Dogg song is most appropriate as they begin their adventure through the streets of LA. Adventure or nightmare, good cop or bad cop, are questions you ask yourself as the movie proceeds. All the while you watch Harris play serious mind games with Hoyt, encouraging him in one breath and literally punking him out in the next. You should enjoy the breakneck speed of this movie and if you're a fan of Washington's acting as I am, you'll enjoy watching him take it to another level.

"Training Day" is by far the most enthralling Cop movie in a very long time. Right from the beginning it breaks down every Hollywood cliche involving the genre, and makes very interesting observations on the dynamics between police and criminals in the LA underworld. The good cop bad cop metaphor is taken to new territory in this film.In the movie, the idealism of rookie cop Jack Hoyt (Hawke) is violently juxtaposed with the Machiavelian cynicism of the veteran detective Alonzo (Washington).(In my opinion Washington gives the most stunning portrayal of a jaded cop since Gary Oldman in "Romeo is Bleeding".)I will not delve into a plot summary, however, I will note that Antoine Fuqua's third film is by far his most truthful and memorable. It stands so far above the entertaining but pointless 'Bait' and the just plain crappy 'Replacement Killers', that I cannot believe that they were made by the same man. In the previous two films it was as if Fuqua was trying to make movies that were to seem that they were autered by more prominent directors (John Woo and Michael Bay to be exact).However, in this film, the director has garnered his own voice, and he has some very important things to say about race, right and wrong, cops and criminals, and about the lines that blur between them all.The true brilliance of this film, however may not be the message that Fuqua wants to convey, but rather the sheer mix of subtlety and outright vicery though which he does convey it. This film is not perfect (which films are?) but it is very important, and it is very ballsy and that is what counts.8.5/10.

I just kept thinking, "How could Jake (Ethan Hawke) even survive so much in one day?" This was an excellent film. Not without its weaknesses, but well-acted and very vivid in its depiction of the undercover narc scene in the LAPD. I don't know how accurate it is, but it makes me wonder about the dirty cops that are out there.

If you can lose yourself in the overall action WITHOUT nit-picking technical issues or plot inconsistancies/holes to the bone, you might enjoy this fast-paced action movie. My personal opinion-from one who has never been on that side of the street-it had a dark, gritty realist feeling.  I know there are cops out there who are tempted to cross the line and do so for whatever motives.  No shocker there.  That one might involve a rookie on his first day and really *(^* with his head, well, hey, I can suspend disbelief if the action is hot.I thoroughly enjoyed seeing Denzel in a villanous role and thought he carried it off to award perfection. DEFINITELY NOT OVER THE TOP- as some have claimed.Ethan Hawke is a good foil as the naive rookie, eager to make dectective grade, who gets an unexpected mentor in Denzel.    Worth seeing again in my opinion.

Denzel and Ethan are indeed excellent in this mostly taut, well paced drama. Denzel's performance as a corrupt cop beautifully rubs against the possibility of excess, but bever crosses the line. Ethan playing an honest cop, looks increasingly bewildered by his unexpected wild ride, but he never loses his footing. Still, Training Day is one of those infuriating movies that could have been much better if the writer and director had trusted the audience more. The movie is seriously undermined by the "motivation" provided for Denzel's corrupt actions on this day, namely, his need to obtain money to pay off the Russian mafia. Denzel's character has already been set up well to have the mixed motivations of ridding the world of major drug figures and, at the same time, enrich himself for the risk he is taking. His complex character, and the tension with Ethan's character, drive the plot. The extra motivation undermines the drama, making it a more standard shoot 'em up. So for most of the film, the tension and drama is high. But the last few scenes undermine the drama.

After seeing this movie , it made me realized how good Denzel Washington is great as an actor(probably one of the best actor ever, if not the greatest...) He(Denzel) does a really good job playing a crook , corrupt cop who takes advantage of his position to commit crimes... and he also uses his apprentice , a rookie cop called Jake(Ethan Hawke) to do something the he(Denzel) has set up... Frankly , i seriously think this was one of Denzel Washington best performance ever and that movie should be considered as a classic gangster movie...However, I think that the ending is great but could have been different , less brutal...Anyway, if you are someone who likes crime , gangster movies you'll will really appreciate this movie

reviews.review_title: Denzel Washington at his very best !
reviews.content: This movie is much more than exceptional. It begins cleverly and increases with enormous intensity as it moves to an overwhelming climax. The Academy Award for best actor must go to Denzel Washington for giving what I believe to be the greatest performance of his career as well as one of the greatest performances of any actor in history.  Denzel is the character, "Alonzo Harris". He uses every existing talent within himself to make the portrayal of this character as "real" as any character that has ever appeared on the screen.  I have always considered Denzel a great actor since I first saw him in "Carbon Copy". He is without question, simply the best actor in the world.  "Training Day" is the vehicle that puts it all out there. Thank you Denzel for caring enough to give the performance of a lifetime.

After seeing this film on DVD, I was truly satisfied with the film; yes, the whole film. There are no plot holes as far as I'm concerned, although I agree that one should see the film again to catch the crucial conversations that reveal some background plot elements -- but it is isn't too hard to catch on to the storyline. Denzel Washington's performance is incredible; viewers will forget his past "good guy" performances as they are absorbed into the dark depth of this crooked, but experienced, narcotics officer.  You will not look at the "crooked cop" idea in the same generic way after seeing this film. He deserved the "Best Actor" Oscar, but it's a bit disappointing (but not TOO much) that it was for a bad guy role, after all of his remarkable previous movie performances. Ethan Hawke's performance as the trainee was very believable as well, for his "training" was a true crucible in deciding whether ridding the streets of criminals took becoming a criminal. Though it's a rough movie in terms of language and thematics, the violence was not as pervasive.  The disturbing imagery gives the film a serious but effective tone in encapsulating street life and the moral clashes between Harris (Washington) and Hoyt (Hawke), and their dealings with real criminals.  Impressive and disturbingly powerful flick.

I had a hard time voting for this one because I had mixed reactions to it. I thought it was choppy and depressing, and probably not too realistic. However the acting was outstanding, and I did enjoy some of the "surprises" in the movie.  This was not what I would call a "feel good" movie!! I'm not even sure if it had an important message.  I would recommend this to people who like to see unique shows,but not to someone who needs a lift...

reviews.review_title: A very realistic taste of L.A.
reviews.content: For someone who lives in L.A., it is easy to overlook the "holes" in the story, including the forced coincidences or the flawed final.  There's too much emotion in this daring story to leave room for cool, logical judgment. This created a paradox: the story may be flawed, but still 100% realistic.  Welcome to L.A., where the most dangerous killer gang is the police, and where half of the city's officials belong in jail.  Both crowds share the same contempt for anything straight, and see the public as enemy.I can fully understand why the authors may have been too carried away by emotion (by their "beef" with the cops and corrupt officials) to analyze their own story in detail.  Denzel is one of the nicest, straightest guys you can imagine in real life - and so are most of the others.  Yes, even the rap singers. Previous critics said all that needed to be said about this movie, excepting its amazing realism outside the story.  That's because most critics live outside Southern California.  Planning a visit to L.A.?  You don't need it - just rent this movie and save a few bucks for a trip somewhere else. The joke with the snail, in the movie, sums it up.  Don't visit L.A. unless you "get it" - otherwise it may be quite a dangerous trip.

I will just say that Denzel is the top dog. I must give him high praise for this because this is his first time being the bad guy and he still gives a tremendously good performance. Denzel plays every character in the movies he's been in very well. It's too bad he had to play a negative role to win an Oscar but that's a separate issue. All in all, Denzel is one of, if not the best out there. I have yet too see a bad Denzel movie and this man has a long history. Few actors can say that. They have at least one stinker. With Denzel you have some better than others but never a bad one.

Denzil was a great actor on this with a fantastic script and hawke also was good
But there is somethings i couldn't understand on the movie
Saw it in NYC and liked it a lot.  Denzel is pretty funny and Eathan was even better. A lot happens in 1 day between these 2. I gave it a 8/10 Enjoy! :D

I went into this film with expectations that I assumed were too high.  But from the opening shot, the film had me hooked and never let me down.  There were only a couple places where I was able to start dissecting it, but then the plot would pick up again right away and I'd be engaged.  This is a great work of fiction based on events that could actually occur and people who probably exist.  After reading a certain "Rolling Stone" article the summer before the film was released about the Death Row Records/Rampart Scandal, I felt that a film like this should be made.  And it was.  (Albeit without the record label angle.)  The acting, directing, writing, and cinematography are all top-notch.

I really wanted to like film more than I eventually did.The film starts off in great fashion with Alfonso's (Washington) character being outlined immediately as an ultra cool narcotics cop with a street reputation and the mean streak required to survive in that type of work, you could not help but warm to his character's style and grace.Hawke plays an understated role as a rookie narc cop undergoing a trial day on the job to see if he can hack it on the mean streets.The plot lets the film down for me. About half way into the film the point seems to get lost somewhere and I was left feeling as if a massive opportunity to make a good film into a great one had passed.Washington is excellent none the less bringing humility, profanity and plenty of guts to his performance.

To be truthful, I didn't really expect to like this movie. I went because, even though I'm an old white broad, I'm mad about Denzel, and who wants to see their heart throb play a cop on the take? I admit that the violence (which I expected) was a bit much for me. Still, I liked the movie. It had a very believable (to me) story line, and the acting was superb! Ladies, put away your squeamishness over blood and guts and accompany your man to see this movie. You won't regret it!

After watching all the special features on the DVD, I gained a better appreciation for this film. Both the director and the writer are "graduates" of project areas in the USA (Director: Pittsburgh, Writer: LA). The cast and crew spent a lot of time researching both the gang situation in east-central LA and the lives of undercover narcs. The film was pre-screened to gang members and the police to ensure its authenticity. This is a gritty, not pretty film. It has not been hollywoodized to appeal to the masses. It doesn't have a happy ending, the good guys don't always win...much like real life. The movie projects a definite shade of gray, so please don't look for black hats and white hats. For Ethan Hawke's character, it is his journey into the Heart of Darkness, with Denzel Washington, as his Kurtz.For those who complain that Denzel Washington won the Academy Award for best Actor; perhaps you should ask yourselves why he was not nominated for Malcolm X, and why he failed to win for The Hurricane. You may find a answer to that question, if you choose to view Training Day.
Every one is talking about Denzel and they are right! But i see Hawk... what a brilliant actor

I have this habit of praising movies, ALL movies, after just seeing them. Its been about 24 hours since I saw Training Day, and I hope I can offer some semblance of a good critique of this film.Once again I fear, a movie has been hyped beyond its prowess.  Going into this movie I had expectations (another bad habit I have) of seeing a "best picture nomination, and best supporting for Ethan Hawke."  Not too smart of me.  Hawke's performance was good, but nothing close to oscar caliber.  If there are going to be any oscar nods for this movie (a far shot) would be for Denzel as best actor.  The movie was good, one of the better ones I've seen this year.  Direction by Fuqua was superb, getting across feelings of suspense and fear when it was needed.  all in all, worth my inflated admission price of $9.00.Go see it.

reviews.review_title: If you really liked the movie check out the DVD with the extras.
reviews.content: I was in love with this movie the first time i saw it and had video for ages. When i got the DVD i discovered that the extras go a long way in helping to understand the way the movie seems so real and where the director, and all those making the movie were coming from. In an uncompromising way the film shows a world that is totally corrupt (in this case the LAPD). The reason that i love this film is because the world (or at least those in power for the past 500 years, respectively) IS totally corrupt. Nice nation leaders get beat back by all the bullies, all the time, and probably for all time!. I love the US TV show 'Law & Order'. I love the older cop with his droopy face and his 'happy-go-lucky'/zen Buddhist attitude to things.But training day, that's like the real world.

Denzel Washington is wonderfully and diabolically evil as we have never seen him before...Ethan Hawke plays his part very well, evolving in one day from innocence to cynicism, anger & violence. The last third of the show went a little overboard, losing some of the believability, but overall it enthralling, albeit sometimes disturbing. (I noticed that Jaime P Gomez from Nash Bridges played the part of one of Denzel's "henchmen" and think that his name should have been on the billing as well as Dr Dre, Snoop Dog, etc.) The entire supporting cast was fantastic, the background was realistic because it was the real thing. On a scale of 10 I would give the movie a 7, and Denzel a 10!

For some reason this movie left me somehwat annoyed, with a sense of missing closure. The ending was a little disappointing, dramatically speaking. The movie shows a lot of effort and is has a professional touch to it, but it somehow leaves you wanting more.

I own training day on DVD and before buying it on DVD i heard mixed reviews so i eventually bought it and thought Denzel Washington's performance was definitely his best performance to date. From the first 5 minutes till the last minute, i was gripped and shocked at what Alonzo woz forcing Hoyt to do by crossing the fine line of law and justice. I also thought Snoop Dogg's performance woz funny but too short, i wasn't keen on Dre's performance. I thought Eva Mendes' look and presence was sexy and lingering. The music set the atmosphere and the dialogue and grubby look of LA set the pace. I watched the DVD twice in the same night and loved every single minute of it. Top Rating!

A good solid performance by Denzel Washington. Ethan Hawke also delivers a stand out performance. A good script and concept to the storyline. The only thing I didn't like was how many bullets were needed for the Russian mafia to kill Antoine. A bit ridiculous but when all is said and done a thoroughly enjoyable film.

I would have thought that every possible angle on the good cop/bad cop treatment had been exhausted.  I would have thought Denzel conquered all the risky roles early in his career, opting now for more subdued, sympathetic, and audience-friendly characters like those in `Remember the Titans' and the inappropriately named `The Hurricane'.  I would have thought that Ethan Hawke had an open clause in his contract about never appearing without facial hair.But Antoine Fuqua's gritty and sobering `Training Day' breaks all the rules. Having developed his craft early on directing music videos and television commercials, he emerged boldly into the box office limelight in 1998 with `Replacement Killers' and then fizzled with last years' disappointing and forgettable Jamie Foxx action yawn `Bait'.  He returns this fall, taking the reigns of a virile and invigorating script by David Ayer, a young writer whose career is still in it's infancy but is already well-established in testosterone-wielding fun with last years `U-571' and Universal Studios summer paycheck `The Fast and the Furious' ($144M at last count).Ethan Hawke birthed his reputation as the quintessential slacker, apparently living in a world where combs, razors, and clothes that fit are luxury items.  Dissolving the typecast, he stars (though less brightly than Denzel) as Jake Hoyt, the idealistic straight-edge officer on his first day in a covert narcotics unit headed up by Denzel's Alonzo Harris.  Hawke's character quickly learns that his initiation into the squad is a one-way street, and he has one day to iron out the ethics of either turning dirty or fighting dirty.Denzel Washington, as the bad-ass deep-undercover corrupt cop, revamps the powerfully watchful and angrily militant guise that he first debuted in `Malcolm X', extending something remarkably spiritual and endearing to the prospect of a police officer playing vigilante or dipping into confiscated drug money.  He maintains the sanctimony and passive aggression that built his career, this time laced with the Tourette's-induced, crazed paranoia that first surfaced in his cop-over-the-edge in `Richochet'.  His role here makes you forget that he previously lent his eponymous notoriety to such self-gratifying box-office fodder as `The Bone Collector' or `Virtuosity' and makes you remember that he once took center stage at the Academy Awards (Best Actor 1989, `Glory').This movie also contains notable cameos from Macy Gray and Dr. Dre, the former displaying the most impractical, keyboard-frightening manicure to grace the big screen since Lon Chaney's Wolfman, and the latter serving up the irony as an L.A. police officer (for more information, see N.W.A.'s 1988 release `F*** the Police').  Snoop Doggy Dogg also had a small but all-too-believable part as a junkie, despite a hectic schedule starring in four releases this year, as well as any movie from the last three years with misspelled titles.  See `Hot Boyz' (1999) or `Tha Eastsidaz' (2000).At first, the mood leans toward that of philosophical street-smart police discipline, but eventually vents it's energy in the struggle between the main characters, with each pushing the other to unrehearsed limits.  The ending feels somewhat like the beginning of a saga - the two battle to a completion that seems eternally incomplete, as the hero and villain confound one another's personalities and seem naturally entwined.  This is a must-see for Denzel fans, and a potent oak-hearted battle of wits, might, and morality that can be appreciated by anyone who thinks that society still has much evolving to do.  Good movie.

reviews.review_title: An intruiging, intense angle to the traditional cop movie
reviews.content: Better than a typical out-of-line-cop action movie, Training Day delivers as a solid drama with enough action to keep things stirring.Ethan Hawke's naive character allows us as viewers to 'feel' the intensity & chaos of L.A.'s back alleys and neighborhoods, while steadily unravelling Denzel Washington's character as an increasingly crooked narc officer who seems to know no boundaries.Perhaps the greatest success of this film is it lacks the predicatability of many other cop movies where the 'rogue cop' does have ultimate limits (i.e. The Negotiator, Bad Boys, etc), because he's really deep down a good guy. In this movie you really have to wonder if, for Washington, that good vs. evil line is ever drawn.I feel the best part of the movie, and most suspensful, is the poker game scene.  It makes a viewer truly identify with the vulnerablitity of being completely isolated, and defensless, amidst a den of cold-hearted strangers.I would recommend seeing this movie, if for any reason to see a slightly different angle to the traditional Hollywood-cop-movie formula.

reviews.review_title: This training is not what he'd expected.
reviews.content: Training Day seems passionately made and well crafted. It's fast paced from the start, scene-to-scene, though slows down at some places, likely for the need of character development. One small scene where Alonzo talks to his son in Spanish, is emotionally captivating, even when one is unaware of the language; and most importantly - describes his somewhat affection for his closed one, amidst his brutal actions and dialogues throughout the movie. What Denzel Washington's character (Alonzo) mostly does is evidently the 'wrong' convention of doing things; it does sometimes looks like this 'cop' has a pretty decent idea about how things work (he even exclaims during one scene, "Nothing's free in this world, Jake. Not even arrest..") This makes Alonzo implausible.The film aptly uses the location of Los Angeles, which suffers from the socio-economic issue of drug cartels and gang wars, also relevant to the plot's context.I've seen it once as of, but definitely wouldn't mind watching again, since it's no-campy, complex story line makes one to delve deeper into it's dialogues, thus increasing it's re-playing ability.

I've seen Denzel Washington play comedy, romance, fantasy, drama, action...and he's always turned in a superb performance.This time he's outdone himself as a total rock bottom villain.I doubt he'll be nominated for an Oscar, because this is not the kind of film the academy usually looks at twice. But his performance is beyond description.The plot moves fast, has several unexpected twists and turns, and keeps the viewer glued to his seat. I didn't even want to blink!Denzel Washington is the finest actor to come along since Jimmy Stewart.

reviews.review_title: Well acted movie with excessive violence and a preposterous plot.
reviews.content: I looked forward to Training Day because of Denzel Washington (Alonzo)and I was well rewarded by his excellent, in-your-face acting. In fact, all the acting was excellent. However, the movie grew more and more violent as it moved along, I thought overtaking the suspenseful first half build-up. By the end, I was sorry we took our teenage daughter. More importantly, the movie's plot doesn't stand up to the plausibility test. Alonzo's driving motivation seems to stem from a hazy, out of the movie run-in he had with Russian gangsters in Las Vegas. Coincidentally or not, the day he must resolve this issue is also an orientation day for rookie Hoyt (Ethan Hawke). Over the course of the day, unlikely yet critical events tumble over one another toward a predictable violent climax. One thing I couldn't figure out: Why would Alonzo choose to live right in the middle of the worst drug neighborhood in LA?

reviews.review_title: Should've been an independent movie - Warner messed it up.
reviews.content: Interesting moral dilemma.About the first half way through the movie, the premise was bright.  A moral story.  A rookie who spends a day training with his new boss narcotics agent discovers that the ways that his boss roots out evil aren't exactly godly. This reminded me of Boiler Room, because in both movies the `rookie' is forced to make a decision between the morality he has and what is being presented to him as moral.  I've never seen Denzel Washington use such foul language.  But in the second half, it just fell flat on it's face.   NO SPOILERS, don't worry. - It looked as if Warner Brothers had forced Village Roadshow pictures to slap on the ending that they did because the moral fable just wasn't enough  that W.B. wanted it to appeal to lower brow audience, perhaps.  Maybe that's why there is such unnecessary violence throughout the movie.  In fact, the ending  no spoilers included  stylized as to look dramatic, but really it is just low-brow.  Should've been an independent movie without the financial backing from WB as WB messed it up.

But is Alonzo the truth the way and the light or a seductive demon? There's enough seduction and mystery to keep us interested. Training Day is a bold and amazing experience. This film goes beyond painting the picture of a bad day as an undercover cop; it draws you into a world that is both frightening and intriguing. Denzel is perfectly cast. He does not just make this role better, he makes it possible. The fact that most of us can not conceive of disliking Denzel Washington is precisely what makes Alonzo Harris ( his character ) compelling. The evil of this crooked "wolf" is so plausibly wrapped in charm and humanity, that the decision to dislike him is painful. Denzel causes us to empathize with Hoyt's ( Ethan Hawke's ) gut wrenching dilemma - the audience is forced into the same, brutal indecision. Hawke skillfully plays his part, and is totally believable. I could identify with his character in every hesitation, and each surrender. All in all, a brilliant film. Not for the faint of heart, but not to be missed.

I hate first days on a new job.  You're nervous, not exactly sure of what to expect and all too often not sure you made the right decision to take the job in the first place.  Jake Hoyt is having such a day as he starts a new job in the narcotics squad with his new bad-ass boss Alonzo Harris. Detective Harris is loud, bad and mean and knows the streets like he was born and bred in them.  Is he for real? Or is he testing Jake to see if he has the right stuff to make it down these mean streets of L.A., we shall see.wont we?Training Day, the just released on video movie that I just got around to seeing, is a nightmare first day on the job film.  It's 24 hours in the life of a rookie who figures on making detective if he joins the narcotics squad and rids the streets of drugs and baddies.  Unbeknownst to him, one of the baddest baddies is sitting right next to him, in the form of the devil himself played by now Oscar winner Denzel Washington.  Denzel's Detective Harris is the devil incarnate make no mistake about it.  He is the tempter in the wilderness, the one who will offer you the world if you would just bow down and worship him.just a little.   Okay, just murder for him and he will grant your every wish and devour your soul in the process.  In the next day, Officer Hoyt will not know what to believe and will not believe his own eyes.  The ideal world he envisioned will disintegrate around him and reduce him to an animal just trying to survive.  Detective Beelzebub will show him that the world is a jungle and there is a fine line between good and evil that cops have to occasionally jump to and from in order to survive.  The lessons being dealt are tough and cruel, to the extent that the film goes from unsentimental reality to surrealism.  No one can be this bad, no one can withstand this kind of punishment and fury, can they?
Being good is so much harder then being bad.  Being deliciously bad is so much fun and Denzel Washington is almost giddy reveling in the flesh of Alonzo Harris.  I could not take my eyes off of him, his line delivery and body language is razor sharp and he is truly one of our most gifted film actors.  Every scene he is in, and he is on camera for 90% of the movie, crackles with electricity, talking street jive and howling like a wolf. Detective Harris is the alpha wolf, the leader of men, the prince of darkness who rules hell because it is preferable to serving in heaven. The film is lifted and sustained by him to heights much higher then the pulp fiction it actually is.  His performance is mesmerizing and deservedly received awards and much praise.Denzel's partner in Training Day, playing Jake Hoyt, is Ethan Hawke.  His job is much harder, he is the good one, therefore the boring voice in the wilderness expressing his concerns and unsure of what to believe and do through most of his grueling first day on the job.  Being good is hard work, and Mr. Hawke actually does a fine job delivering the goods.  In the past, I've found him too introspective to be exciting on the screen.  Too often he blends into the scenery and becomes good-looking Scandinavian furniture. But surprise, he actually holds his own beside the evil one and delivers a solid, respectable performance.Director Antoine Fuqua's Training day is a fantasy disguised as a gritty tough street film about police corruption.  Is this really going on to this extent, I don't really believe it.  Are there bad cops playing both sides of the fence, sure, but the 24 hours on display here are movie hours. Nothing can be believed but it can certainly be enjoyed as a surrealistic trip thru Dante's Inferno via Los Angeles.  Fuqua, much like David Fincher's Fight Club, takes us on a trip through the heart of darkness and I went along for the ride and liked most of it, especially Denzel's turn being so good at playing bad.

reviews.review_title: Great performances in an average, formula blaxploitation film
reviews.content:
In 20 years we will look back at this in the same way we look back at movies like Cleopatra Jones, Friday Foster, Foxy Brown, etc... and will take it for what it is: a cheap portrayal of minorities with the basic message that "those drug sellin', gun carryin' blacks and latinos are just gonna kill each other," except for the occasional hero who really wants to "change the way things are." Formula, formula, formula!  (At least in most blaxploitation movies, the hero gets to be black!)Fantastic performances and a high budget help it to stand above other films in the genre. Now, I really enjoy Pam Grier movies, Dolemite, Cleopatra Jones, Shaft, and so on.  I can watch those and have a great time. I also enjoyed Training Day, but let's be real about what kind of film this is.  At its core, it is blaxploitation.
*** POSSIBLE SPOILERS AHEAD ***Stock characters fill the script: a lone hero who is pure of heart and wants to clean things up, a collection of bad guys with one really bad guy who leads them that's in it for the money, and ultimately "whitey" is in control (the nice, older white gentlemen Alonzo meets in the club.) Unimaginative dialog is  characteristic of the genre and that detail wasn't overlooked here. (How many times can you say "dawg" and "ni**er" without it being repetitive?)Worth seeing for an entertaining time, but not high art.

There is only one reason why this flick will never have its rightful place in Hollywood history. With great anticipation, I watched Denzel Washington (who I believe walks on water) take on his first roll as a bad guy. Even though his performance was stellar, there was just something significantly wrong with this film throughout. While contemplating the thin line between art imitating life and its opposite, consider the following.A Hollywood good guy who takes on the role of a bad guy is best served by pairing with someone who is also reputed as good. Remember the movie "Heat"? Ethan Hawke is not that guy.While the movie was set in the most notorious urban jungle, the good cop managed to do some things that simply can't be done by a white cop in a real environment of the same notoriety. Even people from the squeaky clean suburbs know that downtrodden minorities have no love (or trust) for white police officers simply because they are white (the oppressor). I could go on criticizing Training Day for other little quirks, but it really would not matter. There truly is only one reason why this potentially great movie (great like Gladiator) won't ever be regarded as such. Somebody made a fatal casting mistake. If Cuba Gooding Jr. had been the rookie, you can bet that this movie would have been in line for several Oscar awards. As fate would have it instead, Denzel Washington's first performance as a bad guy may go down in history as a forgettable moment. Imagine a sequel to this movie starring Ethan Hawke now as a veteran. Would you go see it? What a shame... Denzel did such an awesome job!

I don't think I can say anything positive about this movie.

Training Day is a dynamic film about the darkest and most intense side of police work.  The moral dilemnas and predicaments that arise for the aspiring narcotics officer are real problems that officers must face at times.  The movie portrays how some officers find themselves in the "underworld" environment, without ever planning to enter it.The scene in the car, after they do the felony stop on the teenagers, shows how a seemingly strong-minded cop might be manipulated and it all starts there.I was also impressed by the realism as far as police work.  The way the suspects refuse to cooperate, the artificial respect of the dealers with the cops, the drug sell hunting, the drug swallowing, the language, etc.If you're a law enforcement officer, especially a patrol cop, this is a REQUIRED viewing.Let's remember that as extreme as the film might seem, most of it happens regularly in the big cities.  Enjoy.

Okay we've seen Washington play controversial figures before, but there was something about his character in "Training Day" that hit me hard.  How hard? It's best if I draw a comparison:Anyone familiar with "Once Upon A Time in the West"?  Anyone?  Show of Hands?  Let me illustrate the opening scene.  Typical opener for a Western: Low down, yella bellied, rattlesnake types roughing up a small homestead. Roof burning, windows shot up, family dying.  A small child huddles against his parents' lifeless bodies.  A shadow looms over him.  The boy gazes at the man casting the shadow:  From the boots up, up, up, into the leering face of...Henry Fonda.Yes, THAT Henry Fonda."Young Mr. Lincoln" Fonda."Golden Pond" Fonda.HENRY F---ING FONDA.And THAT is the effect Denzel "Detective Alonzo" Washington had on me while watching "Training Day".  The exact same shock some filmgoer in the late sixties would have had the first time Henry clean-as-a-slate Fonda was cast as a scummy murderer.Okay, back to your lives now.  Thanks for hearing me out.

This movie is a must-see for anyone interested in the rim of society. The actual story is rather simple : a young police officer is transferred to the Narcotics department and recieves his "street training" from a hardened, experienced colleage.For an American movie it is quite uncensored. Many, many unwanted aspects of society are part of this movie, putting it in another way : they ARE the movie. It gives an extremely dark, pitch-black image of the edges of modern society and the people trying to control it.The tough, experienced officer forces his colleage through nice words and brute violence to break numerous laws, in order to "adapt to the streets". Towards the end the newbie starts to mentally degenerate, to harden like his mentor, and become a man of the streets himself.

reviews.review_title: A magnificent depiction of a shady world
reviews.content: The magic of the movies is that they allow us to see worlds and experience emotions that are sometimes distant from our own and our immediate environment. Antoine Fuqua in Training day brings to us a world of gangs, drugs and corruption that is alien to must of us, but which nevertheless exists, sometimes transcending its own borders and coming to us in the form of news (The rampart scandal) and no matter if we close our eyes and ignore it, it will not go away. In that world we have two police officers, officer Hoyt, a rookie just assigned to an elite anti narcotics unit, and officer Alonzo, a veteran of the force, commanding the unit. Each one of those officers has his own set of values and morality, but no one is completely good or completely evil as absolute evil or absolute good are inexistent (in humans at least), ultimately they just want to take care of their own problems. Hoyt wants to take care of his family, his young wife, his new born child, he wants to escalate positions (don't we all) in the force and this new assignment may be the perfect place to start and he will do anything to nail it. Officer Alonzo has a more complicated set of problems, he has to get a million dollars and he has to do it today; otherwise he will be killed by the Russian mafia, but he has a plan and the plan involves Hoyt (a virgin shooter above suspicion) and Roger (a drug dealer with a lot of money in his kitchen floor). Basically the movie unfolds as Alonzo's plan goes into motion showing us glimpses of a corrupt and disturbing world, a world with its own rules and twisted morality, Smiley forgiving Hoyt's life as a return for having protected his cousin's honor, gang members shooting indiscriminately to protect the sandman's property, Stan and his friends giving Alonzo carte blanch to basically kill Roger and steal his money so he can save himself, etc. Denzel Washington work was impeccable; a well deserved Oscar, showing us a man who has moved the line a little bit each time to the point that he doesn't know where he is now, a man who has moved to the edge in a desperate attempt to save his life. Is he really that bad? After all he is a father, a husband, a friend appreciated by his team (if you think you can get away with it, we are with you) and colleagues. Maybe we just caught him in a bad day...a training day. If we want to make a better society for every one, we have to know what are the obstacles we have to overcome, training day show us some of those obstacles and then some.

Training Day is what I would consider THE best movie of 2001, and the best Denzel Washington movie ever made. However the release of the film hurt its chances of being an Oscar contender by releasing it late summer. If it had been released during Christmas it would have been getting the rave reviews as A Beautiful Mind and Black Hawk Down have been receiving. It is without a doubt, the most underrated movie of 2001.Although, I am glad to have seen Washington nominated for Best Actor in the Golden Globes, hopefully the Academy will carry that over to the Oscars.Acting is superb, especially with Ethan Hawke! With a supporting cast such as Dr. Dre and Snoop Dogg -- who were unexpectedly GREAT actors, despite their short screen presence (there are no small parts, only small actors.)The realism of the movie makes you think that the director actually went out on the streets of LA and actually filmed the real lives of corrupted cops and druglords. This movie is a MUST BUY DVD or VHS.

reviews.review_title: Great acting for a horrible plot and script
reviews.content: (Some spoilers here)I thought that the plot of this movie was just horrible. The movie was somewhat complex, but we don't ever see Alonzo's motives or anything like that until Jake meets Smiley and his crew. Before, it's just like hey, let's go here and beat this rapist, then this druggie, etc. This movie is the type of film that I would typically abhor to see because the script in my opinion was too redundant at times.If anything saved this film, it was the casting. Denzel Washington and Ethan Hawke gave the best possible performances in this otherwise crappy film. They fit their characters' roles perfectly and you can see it in their eyes. I am wondering why Ethan Hawke wasn't nominated for Best Actor along with Denzel Washington, instead of Best Supporting Actor at the Oscars as I think Hoyt is also a main character. Nevertheless, this acting duo is what has made a film with a horrible script viewable, because Training Day is the worst script with the best possible actors. This is definitely shown because Training Day had two Oscar nominations, for Best Actor and Best Supporting Actor, and nothing else. Denzel Washington of course won the movie's only Oscar, but I don't know if this was his best performance ever. Nevertheless, Washington deserved the Oscar in 2001, and he is finally recognized as one of THE premier actors in Hollywood.
